page.title: 19Local History - Place-names
page.content: A mixture of Welsh and later Saxon names occur as this was part of the ancient Celtic kingdom of Ergyng, between the rivers Wye, Worm and Monnow. Llanwarne derives from Llan-wern,and earlier Llan-guern, the church by the alders. St.Weonard's, named after a Celtic St. Wenardus Heremyta, has an ancient tump by the church. Charcoal and burnt human bone fragments, also Roman coins have been excavated. Pencoyd means 'head of the wood'. Trebaron is the house of the animals. Llandinabo, named after St.Inabwy or St. Dinabo, is mentioned in the 7th century Book of Llandaff as a gift of land to St.Dubricius. Similar gifts of land are recorded in Llanwarne. Michaelchurch was a chapelry joined to Tretire & part of the Guy's estate.
